newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka capital placed on alert for rebel bombers.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka capital placed on alert for rebel bombers.

text.p: Colombo police on Thursday warned the public to be on the alert for suspected Tamil suicide bombers who may have infiltrated the city's defences, Colombo police chief D.M. Dissanayake said.

The warning came as 22 suspected Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) activists escaped from a high-security prison in Trincomalee, 240 km (150 miles) northeast of Colombo, military officials said.
Ten activists were killed or captured, while 12 remained at large, military officials said.
"We are told that many (rebels) have infiltrated Colombo," Dissanayake told Reuters. "They will try their level best to do things. So we have warned the public to be on the alert."
Earlier this week police headquarters issued posters and stickers urging the public to cooperate with security forces, mainly by being on the lookout for suspicious characters, he said.

Security has been tight in the Sri Lankan capital since January when the rebels, fighting for independence in the island's north and east, detonated a truck bomb outside the central bank, killing about 100 people.
In July, they set off bombs in a crowded passenger train in a Colombo suburb, killing 57.
Earlier this month, police arrested a group of 20 suspected rebel suicide bombers near President Chandrika Kumaratunga's official residence.
Military officials in Trincomalee said the LTTE suspects broke out of jail shortly before midnight on Wednesday after grabbing a guard's gun.
Soldiers gave chase, shooting five of them dead and arresting five more, they said. Two military policemen were killed in the shootout. The other 12 suspects are at large.
The Sri Lankan government says more than 50,000 people have been killed in the ethnic conflict, which is in its 14th year, while the LTTE says a much higher number have perished.
